message: I'm working on http://www.taskranger.com/
In terms of time-tracking I can wholeheartedly endorse Freckle. http://letsfreckle.com. It integrates w/lotsa cool stuff, even has a cool timer on the site.
I can't seem to find the perfect To-do app. I liked Flow (getflow.com), but not (yet) willing to pay for it
Take a look at the time tracker component in Freshbooks.  You can have a free account for up to 3 clients. http://www.freshbooks.com/timetracking.php
I'm working on http://publiclog.com  (Keep A Public Log About What's Happening)
I made this years ago, still use it every day: http://trails.es ... still in Alpha ;) (don't try to move a task from one list to the next, it will break your account)
@jca Watch out for feature creep!
@problem Hmm?  You think I'm trying to do too much?
Cuz I'm planning on doing a lot more :)
@loganlinn I can't seem to find something that truly lives up to my expectations neither. I have started seriously considering making my own :p

Wunderlist for tasks - it's awesome. iPhone, iPad, Windows Mac Linux... everywhere. Cloud app too. For time tracking (and invoices, billing etc) I use RoninApp since they have an iPhone app for time tracking also and I do lots of offline client work, so that comes in handy.
http://mite.yo.lk/ works very well for my time tracking.
@Lloyd RoninApp looks nice. I'm currently using Fanurio which is a pure client app which  works.
it's my data and I don't really want anybody to have that data. even if it's been aggregated.
@adsworth Oh it's awesome. Basic task management, assign tasks to other people in your team, invite freelance contractors etc... really handy.

@Lloyd although I don't really like this sentence in their privacy policy: "Ronin also collects and stores any information provided during usage of the Applications. This information will not be disclosed to any third-party without your explicit consent, except as aggregate, statistical information that will not include any identifying information."
Aggregate anonymous data. It could be anyones data. Why does it bother you?
I'd be paying them to supply me with an application and to store my data and that's it. If I get it for free, then go ahead and make money with the data you collect.
If one can find out whether I visited a site just by having me display the link in my browser plus a little JavaScript. How can I be sure that it has been anonymized correctly.
@adsworth that line of privacy policy is pretty common. the idea is collecting usage data so they'll know what features to add or kill. making an app better is a lot easier with real data
http://tasskr.com
@jca indeed sir - do some user testing: http://usertesting.com and http://usabilityhub.com
@unwrangle for the usage data they have a separate paragraph and I don't have any problems with that. It just the 3rd party that annoys me in the mentioned paragraph.
@adsworth fair enough...
@problem  Cool links, I'll give 'em a whirl for sure.  I've been using http://feedbackroulette.com

And I see what you're getting at about overwhelming users with complexity.  But I think every feature in there so far is really useful once you understand it.  Eventually I want to make it so things start out really simple and then the advanced features are optionally  revealed as you use the tool -- or something like that.  I think that well help a lot.
@jca I really like the keyboard navigation but please consider adding/switching to vim keybindings!  I want to use it but I know I'm going to constantly be pressing L when I should press R, etc.. :p
We started a StartupWeekend Kan-Ban style multi-user task and time tracker at http://pandatask.pageforest.com.  Under active development, so more features coming over the next couple of weeks.
That said, this is an interesting approach :)  And open source is cool.  And page forest looks interesting.
@sequoia Sure, I'll put a vim keys option on the to-do list.
@mckoss  Good god.  It seems like everybody and their mother is working on a task management tool.
The ctrl+* keyboard shortcuts aren't working for me.
I use nirvanahq.com
@meeech can i get an invite code?
Been trying Wunderlist. I can see how it gets the job done. So far, I like having a native app for my phone. Don't have a problem using web app in browser though
@themusicninja invite code not needed anymore.

I'm a co-founder and developer at Interstate (http://interstateapp.com). We let you plan your project using roadmap(s) which you can then, if you want to of course, share with your end-users via our API to offer an increased level of transparency. A roadmap contains several "roads" which can have a title, description, start/due dates, a progress status ("Proposed", "Started", 0-90%, "Ready", "Launched" and "Stopped"). You can also post text updates to roads as you progress through development.
if you decide to check it out and apply for an invite shoot me a DM with your app/email and i'll send out an invite :)
www.toggl.com for time tracking
emacs org-mode haha

To-do: Google Tasks (great integration with Google Mail and Calendar) together with the GTasks app: https://market.android.com/details?id=org.dayup.gtask There is also an API: http://code.google.com/apis/tasks/
for time tracking I can recommend http://mite.yo.lk/
@eik3 thanks for that link. found some nice online billing apps from the mite site here in .de
Doesn't track time but for to-do its freaking awesome: http://www.workflowy.com elegant and simple enough that I actually love using it.
Has anyone mentioned todoapp.me ?
Things for Mac and iOS is still my favorite. Just works like a charm!
for todos I like http://anxietyapp.com/ and Things (http://culturedcode.com/)
Billings (http://www.marketcircle.com/billings/) is the only app I've used for time tracking.
org-mode for all

On my iPhone I use Rex Lists. I like it because it lets me prepare template which includes many tasks and then i can have many same processes with different names and states all using the same template.

for offline time tracking also take a look at http://www.getklok.com/. What I like about it is that it stores everything in a plain Sqlite database that I can keep/export even long after I'll stop using the application.
@azer damnit emacs.
I use http://todoist.com/. Really simple but gets the work done without getting in your way
If you want to track time against billable projects I've started using Harvest ( http://www.getharvest.com/ ).  They have apps for mobile phones and the Web interface is nice and clean.
+1 for harvest, though I am interested in what the free options are, I don't do that much billing or have that many open projects.
I like toggl (cuz it works on Linux), Evernote, toodledo, egretlist, and workflow. I'm also gonna check out tasskr.
Sry above I meant workflowy
@Lloyd Wunderlist has a Linux client?
http://teambox.com
@jpwdesigns I tried to sign up for workflowy, and I think I crashed their server...
http://imgur.com/meWVR
working now though, it's pretty awesome
@ipwdesigns +1 for workflowy as a simple todo list, best out there and it supports sharing which was a requirement for sharing lists for my small little side projects.
+1 for workflowy, but had no idea it supports sharing! will have to look into that!!
@barcelonafc Don't think so, but I think it's planned.
@Lloyd ok. I guess I'll just use the web version...
Wunderlist: show Linux fanboys some love and make a native Linux client! Pretty pleeeaaassseee...
@odwyerrob Wow that sucks. Well I use it every day and have never seen any signs of server trouble. Its pretty lightweight from appearances. Maybe give it another try.
Try Gina Trapani's app ToDo.txt http://todotxt.com/ It's a command line app that is pretty versatile.  You can also use the android app and sync it with you desktop via dropbox.
Very very nice web app you can install own your own http://www.mytinytodo.net/

What's great about Workflowy is that it keeps all your notes organized.  Basically, it is a single list that you can zoom into and out of infinitely.  So you always have a mental map of how your notes are organized spatially.
+1 for workflowy.com for its elegance and flexibility
WorkFlowy for the win!
I'm using Things for iPhone. It's okay. Not perfect.
